content.description: On the western side of the Slab Land boulder (the big slabby boulder west of Fingerhut).
content.location: Start with your left hand on the incut edge and your right on a pocket, follow the rail up to the well chocked flake and top out.

content.description: A cool little boulder with the crux right off the ground. Start on a little boulder sitting, and power up through a couple of small holds, and finish on solid jugs.
content.protection: 1-2 pads, since it's an uneven landing.
content.location: Left of Dyno Time, the v5 on the Scrawny Boulder.

content.description: Stand start with right hand on well-chalked jug to the left of Whiskey Sweats.  Push hard on a scant right foot, left hand up to a solid ledge.  Easy mantle.
content.location: Leftmost route on the west side of the Slabland boulder.

content.description: This is a very hard one move wonder.  Start on two shallow dishes; there's a single little point that's good for the index finger on your right hand and the rest is rubbish.  Establishing your feet for the move up to the left may be the crux.
content.location: Just up around to the right from Scrawny and Brawny.

content.description: Start low on huecos and climb up and left through slopers and pinches into a juggy finish.
content.location: About 100 feet south of Finger Hut above the steep wash.

content.description: Walk up slopey dishes to an easy mantle.
content.location: To the right of Canadians Finest. 20 years uphill of Man Size boulder.

content.description: The pocket/dish holds to the right of Canadians Finest. Really easy walk up to the top of the boulder.
content.location: On the eastern side of the Slabland boulder. To get to Slabland head west from the Fingerhut boulder. Skyy is the route to the right of the big, well chalked horn of Canadians Finest.

content.description: Climb up and left to the corner/flake.

Start on Great White's start hold and head right, continuing along the right arete until the apex of the boulder. Please comment below if you know the actual name/grade.

Note: I believe this problem eliminates the left arete though I could be wrong. Either way, it felt a bit harder and more fun to me without it.
content.location: See above, Great White is about 200ft above  (up the hill from) the Fingerhut boulder.

content.description: Start on sloper edges to the right of the first move rail of Scrawny and Brawny (the right start hand of that problem can be used as a starting foot). Traverse right around the arete then move up to a crimp near the lip and top out
content.location: To the right of Scrawny and Brawny on two sloper edges about headish height

content.description: Easiest way down on Scrawny and Brawny Boulder. NW Corner where it meets up with another boulder. Climb up from in between the two boulders on jugs and mantle up
content.location: NW Corner of Scrawny and Brawny Boulder

content.description:
2019 Update: The right starting hand broke off, and now this is much easier than the original V10.

The first move is the hardest on this problem, and if steep crimps aren't your thing then you might do well to look elsewhere. Powerful moves straight out of a cave on small but positive holds with tricky footwork is what this one is all about.
content.location: Next to Kind of Brawny, on the right side of the huge boulder.

content.description: Climb up the short, low-angle slab.

A wonderful little problem. Start with underclings, and power out, using careful footwork, through the big holds to the lip. Manage the sloper (oh god, I want to share the really cool easy beta on this, but I'll let you figure it out on your own!), love the throw to the sharp hold, and do the rock over onto the face. Once you are established on the face, it's over.

I thought climbing to the finish on this was easier than climbing up the "Downclimb" on this boulder.
content.location: If you find Fingerhut on the front of the boulder, look around to the farthest corner. If you are looking at Michaelangelo and Ankle Deep In Gasoline, this line is under the right side. Look for the steep undercut.

content.description:
(a.k.a. The Tan Streak) Climb the face straight up the tan streak. The crimps are super sharp!

This problem is also called "Obtuse" in the Caldiero guidebook.
content.location: On the Triangle Boulder.  This problem climbs the tan streak.

content.description: Sit start on opposing crimps. Climb the arête on slopey pockets and pinches to the highest point of boulder. Easy mantle.
content.location: On the Triangle Boulder just past the Scrawny and Brawny boulder. It's the left arête.

content.description: Champagne Supernova Start, Cosmos finish. A bit inobvious, but absolutely awesome rock and moves, especially at this grade. I am fairy sure this is unrepeated but please post here if you know otherwise!
content.location: See above

content.description: Stand start on crimp flakes, easy mantle.
content.location: Far right of the West face of the Slab boulder

content.description: A gorgeous climb up the slightly less than vertical face using unique shallow pockets and crimps just left of the arete. Large move -mentally cruxy- near the top.
content.protection:
Pads and a spotter recommended. Highball.

I took the fall from just below the lip on doubled up pads and was fine.

content.description: You start on the side of a crack and you work your way up to another crack which takes you most of the way up the boulder. you want to top out on the right of the little trees.
content.location: The climb is down the trail that finger hut and the comedian is on. You should pass 2 or 3 boulders to get to this one.

content.description: For this climb you start on the lowest hold with chalk and go slightly right. You should end up left of the little trees top out

The climb combines the boulders Obscelete and The Triangle. Sit start on the very left arete where Obscelete starts. Climb up the arete until the lower pocket line leads to the right. Traverse into The Triangle and follow it to the top.
content.location: The problem is located at The Triangle boulder.

content.description: Sit down start on two good crimps and dyno up to a sloper.  It's a bit of a one-move-wonder and the hardest part for me was keeping my feet off the ground as they swung out, but it's still fun.
content.location: On the main boulder in the Man Size area, on the right downhill corner.

content.description: Characterized by the tough over the lip section, with big reaches on small holds with your feet far below. Awkward for sure. Starts reaching from big holds at head height and then you reach over the lip and get good, then small holds that you have to power through to finish.
content.location: Right of Dyno Time on the Scrawny boulder.

content.description: Same start as Great White, but mantle directly over arete.
content.location: 10yds behind Ankle Deep in Gasoline

content.description:
(a.k.a. The Triangle) Start in the lowest crimps and climb straight up the black face using very sharp crimps and pockets.

Also called "Isosceles" in the Caldiero guidebook.
content.location: On the Triangle Boulder.  4 feet right of The Tan Streak.

content.description:
BOULDER TO THE LEFT IS OFF.

Start with 2 hands on the low hold circled in the photos (bottom right of boulder). Climb left around the protrusion and top out. The Boulder to the left is off for hands and feet. If you were to use it, this would become a boring short V0, instead you get some interesting and powerful movement with a thoughtful topout. I’m sure this has been climbed, but we were messing around and I found this version pretty enjoyable, message me if anyone knows what I should change the name to
content.protection: Throw a pad on the edge and maybe a couple below for if you slide.
content.location: weird overhanging feature to the right of Skyy on the Slabland boulder

content.description: A fun shorty: Start on a low juggy edge, move up to the arete, and coast to the high point.
content.location: 10yds behind from Ankle Deep in Gasoline

content.description: Most interesting because you combine a crimp pinch and a techy heel at the crux. Pretty fun, if you don't mind how short and thrutchy it is.
content.location: On the corner between the Scrawny face and the Dyno time face.

content.description: Start same as finger hut but when you get the first or second move (whatever feels better) go strait up to a really small sharp crimp then the jug.
content.location: same as finger hut

content.description: This was the first V10 at Joe's Valley.  Start sitting down low on a small crimp and a sidepull/gaston, fire up to a sharp crimp, then move right along the seam before firing a dyno between jugs before the topout.  Classic problem.
content.location: The lowest boulder at the Mansize area.  The problem is on the overhanging downhill face of the boulder.

content.description: Start on one high sloper sidepull right hand and one small sharp crimp left hand, go up and left for topout. the bottom of this climb is v7
content.protection: Just 2 pads, a spotter for the rock behind you.
content.location: up the trail and right from little knives boulder.

content.description: I’m not sure about the grade on this, it could be v6 or v8 but it’s around v7. you start on one left hand undercling jug, and a right hand crimpy pinch. you move up the 2 aretes and follow the stand start.
content.protection: Only needs 2 or 3 pads, have a good spotter for tracks boulder on your back.
content.location: Not far up the trail and to the right of little knives boulder.

content.description: Locate the large undercling hold at about 5 feet and match hands.  Paste your feet and cross left hand to the starting left dish of "Dyno Time."  Bust right and gain the big right side pull and then go again either left or right and top out on jugs.  This is a low start to the already established Dyno on Scrawny and Brawny boulder.
content.location: The south side of the scrawny and brawny boulder.

content.description: This is the very fun obvious dyno on the uphill side of the main boulder in the area.  Start on the high jugs and throw out to the chalked hold on the lip.  For an added challenge try a two-hand dyno or try going to some of the slopers just to the left.
content.location: Uphill side of the large boulder.

content.description: Not bad, but nothing to write home about. Start on the big ledge and mantel in there, then stand up to big edges, and crux at the topout mantle.
content.location: On the left side of the Scrawny face, look for a big ledge at the base and a stepped overhang.

content.description: Climb the southwest face just right of the arete using good jugs and pockets.  This problem is also the easiest way off of the Man Size Boulder so make sure you can get down this one before you go up anything else.
content.protection: Don't fall from the top of this one.

content.description: Sit start with left hand on slopey crimp right hand on a large slopey pod.  Climb the overhanging arete on slopey edges to positive holds where you can then pull over on to the face for a highball finish on easy terrain.
content.location: Located on the arete just left of Fingerhut on the Mansize boulder.

content.description: Start on Moose Drool and follow the crimp rail left to finish at the top of Whiskey Sweats.
content.location: Right to Left on the West face of the Slab Boulder

content.description: Start low on jug, move through a complex of holds, and pounce for a good sloper.
content.location: Per BH: The Cosmos Boulder is above the Man Size area. Past the Triangle boulder walk up hill following the wash to your left. After about 5-10 min the wash will bend to the left. The Cosmos boulder is in the middle of the wash and is very obvious.

content.description:
sit start on the right arete next to Finger Hut.  Work your way up the arete, eventually working your way to the jug at the top of finger Hut.  Top out as for Finger Hut.

This problem has been referred to as "Stand Up Comedian" as well.  Perhaps the standstart variation?
content.protection: 2 pads, spotter.  move pads as you go.  there is a huge boulder you're climbing over but it is a clean landing
content.location: On the northeast corner of the Mansize boulder.  It should be the first problem you see when approaching the area.

content.description: Climb up thin holds with bad feet at first.

Start under a roof with a right heel, and progress out the roof to a good left hand, then up sculpted crimps until you can turn the corner and top out right of the arete.

A cool 3d boulder problem with great movement and rock quality.  I suspect it's harder for shorter people but there is all sorts of potential for tricky height specific beta.
content.location:
Immediately right of Cosmos, starting under a low roof under an arete.

To locate the boulder itself, follow a faint trail up the wash from the triangle boulder for about 5 minutes.  The boulder is in the wash and is quite obvious.

content.description: The pockets up to the big horn. Located to the right of the big rail on the eastern side of the Slabland boulder.
content.location: The pockets up the eastern side of the Slabland boulder. Get to the Slabland boulder by heading west from Fingerhut to the big square boulder

content.description:
start in the pockets. Follow the pockets up and to the right to a bomber crimp.

Also called "Regular" in the Caldiero guidebook.
content.location: On the Triangle Boulder.  This is the problem furthest to the right when facing the boulder.

content.description: Climb up the obvious line of shallow pockets in the center of the wall.

Start in underclings, do a top shelf style single move to the perfect slot and finish as you like. I finished direct, though one can easily escape over to the finish on Interstellar at around the same grade. Since I have to suggest a number I will go with the above, though it very well could be as hard as V9 and as easy as V6, I really don't know. Give it a go and let us all know here!
content.protection: Pads, a few are helpful if solo.
content.location: Start in underclings, LH being quite small and RH large and slopey about 1ft to the right of the start hold for Champagne Supernova.

content.description: On the fingerhut boulder. Climb the arete opposite of Poricini Portobello. Looking at Michelangelo it is down and to the right. Sit start on obvious flat finger-slot holds, cross left hand to a good sloper, come right hand to a small crimp by the sloper, go right hand high to a small crimp-gaston, match, then go go to the pinch on the arete and finish on poricini portobello.
content.location:
Starts low and right of Michelangelo and left of Porcini or Portabello on the Fingerhut Boulder

This problem is not in the Isaac Caldiero guide book.

content.description: Stand start. Crimps and flakes to hole near top. Listed in guidebook as a V4, but felt very easy to me.
content.location: To the left of Michelangelo.

content.description: Stand start on the far left side of the Slab Land boulder. Head straight up through crimps to a big layback rail system.
content.protection: A pad or two, and a spotter would be nice
